text: on Red Square today there was Pompey and
there was patriotism amid tension with
the west of the Ukraine Russia marked
the true day with a massive military
parade Victory Day is a sacred day in
this country more than 20 million Soviet
citizens were killed in World War two
the guests of honor were those who'd
fought Nazi Germany and survived they'd
brought their families along to share
their glory addressing the veterans
President Putin said it had been in the
Soviet people's iron will which had
saved Europe from slavery roughly of
Aragua utter up though it was our
country he said that had chased the
Nazis to their lair and after the troops
rolled the tanks Moscow parading some of
its most modern military hardware a
warning to the West to take Russia
seriously and to avoid confrontation
this display of military might and
patriotic fervor isn't just about
honoring the heroes of the past it sends
a very clear message about today's
Russia which sees itself once again
as a superpower there were Victory Day
parades away from Moscow - this was SIV
estoppel in the Crimea the Ukrainian
Peninsula which Russia annexed earlier
this year President Putin has flown
there this afternoon a visit which is
likely to spark an angry reaction from
the West but in eastern Ukraine instead
of celebration confrontation there are
reports of clashes between Ukrainian
security forces and pro-russian
activists in the town of Mariupol the
West has accused Russia of stoking
separatist sentiment in this region
but that criticism isn't denting Russian
pride there is a wave of patriotism
sweeping this country making President
Putin more popular than ever
Steve Rosenberg BBC News Moscone
